Amphibian wings and bird wings. Ambidromic insects have wings for flight and for mating. Bird wings are mainly flying. Not quite similar. S. Arachnoid skin and bird wings. Arachnids have webbed feet for capture, bird wings are flying. Different functions. T. Nodules on shell and vertebrae on spine. Both are structural elements, but one relates to defense (nodules) and the other to support (vertebrae). Not exactly similar. U. Xiphus and taxons. Not sure about these terms. V. Mitochondria and chloroplasts. Both are organelles within cells, same function. This is a classic example of convergent evolution, where mitochondria and chloroplasts evolved similarly due to their role in energy production. W. Spine ridges and leaves of plants. Spine ridges help prevent slippage, plant leaves provide shade. Different structures but same function, so this is another good fit. X. Whiskers and teeth. Whiskers are for taste, teeth for eating. Different functions. Y. Fluff and feathers. Fluff is for insulation, feathers for warmth. Different materials but same function. Z. Earlobes and paws. Earlobes support hearing, paws for walking. Different functions.

F seems better because both serve as tools for eating.

Convergent evolution often refers to traits that arise independently in different species. For example, both birds and mammals have beaks for eating. Similarly, both birds and mammals have teeth for eating, which is another instance. However, the question asks for the best exemplification, so either could be correct.

Looking back, I think H is a stronger example because it's a well-known case of convergent evolution—the wings of insects and birds. The beaks and teeth are both adaptations for eating, which is a fundamental need shared by many organisms. On the other hand, F is also a good example, but perhaps H is more universally recognized.
